newsitem.title: USA: IPL says all crude lines restarted Friday.
newsitem.headline: IPL says all crude lines restarted Friday.

text.p: IPL Energy Inc restarted the last of its downed crude pipelines Friday evening after repairing a small leak on the line in a Canadian region southwest of Winnipeg, Manitoba, an IPL spokesman said.
"Basically at the end of the day what resulted is that 583,700 barrels did not move due to the shutdown," said IPL's Jeff Mann, noting just five to 10 barrels of heavy crude leaked from the line.
The other three lines, two carrying crude and one carrying refined products, were not leaking and were quickly restored, the spokesman said.
"The 'weeper' was on line three, which is our (heavy crude) line," Mann said, using an industry term used to describe small leaks.
He said the cause of the leak was not yet known and that the company was continuing to work with Canada's Transportation Safety Board to identify the cause.
Mann noted the regulating body could prescribe additional measures besides the repairs IPL performed Friday to prevent any leakage from reoccurring on the line.
The other lines IPL pulled out of service following a report from a nearby resident of an oil smell were: line one, a refined products line, and lines 2b and 13, both crude oil lines, Mann said.
IPL restarted the repaired line three late Friday at 1820 MST/0020 GMT, after shutting all four lines lines Friday morning at 0529 MST/1129 GMT.
It had restarted lines one, 2b and 13 by noon MST/1800 GMT, Mann said.
IPL's Interprovincial pipeline system, which can move up to 1.8 million barrels per day of liquids, combines with the Lakeside system on the U.S. side of the border.
The system, running from Edmonton, Alberta through Superior, Wisconsin and Chicago to various points in southern Ontario, is the world's longest crude oil and liquids pipeline complex.
